question.text: In gravity-free space, a man of mass <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>M</mi></math> standing at a height <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>h</mi></math> above the floor throws a ball of mass <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi></math> straight down with a speed <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>u</mi></math>. When the ball reaches the floor, the distance of the man above the floor will be

solution.text: Due to conservation of momentum in the vertical direction, the man will begin to move up with speed <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="italic">m</mi><mi mathvariant="italic">u</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="italic">M</mi></mfrac></math>. The ball will reach the floor in time<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi> </mi><mfrac><mi mathvariant="italic">h</mi><mi mathvariant="italic">u</mi></mfrac></math>. In this time the man will move up by <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced separators="|"><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi><mi>u</mi></mrow><mi>M</mi></mfrac></mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mfenced separators="|"><mfrac><mi>h</mi><mi>u</mi></mfrac></mfenced></math>. Total distance of man from floor <math><mo>=</mo><mi>h</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="italic">m</mi><mi mathvariant="italic">h</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="italic">M</mi></mfrac></math>.
